_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Horizon Stevedoring operates a cold storage warehsouse at Pier 82 South, Philadelphia, PA. AT this facility, we store fruit transported in by ship from Central and South America.

Like most cold storage warehouses, we use anhydrous ammonia in our refrigeration system.  Ammonia is the best refrigerant available for our use.  Because of its maderate toxicity and slight flammability, ammonia is consedered a hazardous material.  

Horizon is committed to maintaining a safe warehousing operation for our employees and the surrounding community.  Out refrigeration system obeys our loal building and fire codes, as well as industry-consensus codes and stadards where applicable.  Finally, to comply with the requirements of OSHA and the EPA, we have a Process Safety Management program to hop us operate and maintain the system safely.

Our priority is to prenent accidental releases of hazardous materials instead of merely responding to problems.  Our Process Safety Management porgram includes elements addressing:
Employee participation.  We involve our employees at all appropriate points in the program.
Process Safety information.  We maintain information relating to the safety of ammonia and the desing limits of the regrigeration system so that our employees are fully informed.
Precess Hazards Analysis.  We conduct detailed studies of our refrigeration system to important hazards and safeguards.
Operating Procedures.  WE provide written operating pricedures to help staff stay within the safe operating limits of the refrigeration equipment.
Mechanical Integrity (Maintenance and Quality Control). WE are establishing a comprehensive program of inspcetions and preventive maintenance to keep mechanical failures from occurring.
Training. WE train our mechanics in safe operation and maintenacne of the refrigeration system.
Management of Change.  Alterations to the refrigeration system are screened to verify that they are within the original safe design limits.
Pre-Startup Safey Revie

w. For certain types of major changes, we conduct a formal safey review before starup to ensure that the new equipment has been desinged and installed properly.
Contractors.  We caefully screen contractors who work on our property to ensure that they have a safe work record.
We stricly control the welding and other work that could start a fire near the ammonia equipment.
Emergency Response. WE coordinate our resonse to emergencies wht the Phladelphia Fire Deparment.
Incident Investigation.  After an incident, we investigate to determine the causes and any suitable actions to address them.
Compliance Audits.  Approximately every three (3) years we examine the safety program in detail to identify areas for improvement.
Trade Secrets.  OSHA and EPA require us to maintain a trade secrets progam in case confidential information affecting the safety of the ammonia refrigeration system is found.
Management System.  An overall management system monitors the ongoing progress of safety items.

As required by the EPA, we have analyzed "worst-case" and "alternative" hypothetical ammonia release scenarios and their consequences, details of which appear in other portions of the Risk Management Plan.  The methodology used to evauate these accidents is prescribed by regulation, and makes no effort to estimate the likelihoo or "risk" of these incidents.

The "worst-case" release scenario involves loss of the contents of a high-prssure receiver vessel over ten (10) minutes.  As required, this scenario has offsite impact, meaning that a level of 200 ppm ammonia is reached beyond the property line.

Findings of Compliance audit requiring response:

Contractors do not participate well in PSM program.
Information about safety programs and performance need to be obtained from the contractors, and information aboujt hazards existing in the facility as well as those posed by te contractor's work is not formaaly exchanged.  A contractor illness and injury log is not currently maintained.  Co

nfirmation that the contractor is successful in implementing its obligations under the process safety mangement regulations (ie; employee training in the Emergency Action Plan) needs to be periodically checked.
Some process safety information needs replacement and should be rebuilt to the requirements of the 29CFR1910.119(d):
Material and energy balances
Ventilation sytem design and documentation
Electrical classification statement
Relief system design/design basis documentation
Written documentation on the prevenance of old equipment (verbal information is available).
List of codes and standards used for design and construction.
Note that some of the information listed above is partially available or available implicitly in the current process safety information.
Process Safety Analysis revalidation is overdue.
Operating procedures need to be checked for consistency with Contractor, and needs certification.
Operator training needs to have agreed upon refresher every 3 years.
Maintenance procedures need to be verified.
The facility EAP needs procdures for small spills and notificaitons to the Loal Emergency Planning Committee, the State Emergency Response Commission and the National Response Center.
The program needs an update to the Incident Investigation procedures to update/resubmit the Risk Management Plan within 6 months of any reportable incident, due to 2004 regulation change.
